trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Mobile Services to authenticate users of your Universal Windows 8.1 app by using various identity providers, including Google, Facebook, Twitter, and Microsoft.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Mobile Services to authenticate users of your Universal Windows 8.1 app by using various identity providers, including Google, Facebook, Twitter, and Microsoft.

trans-unit.source: Add authentication to your Mobile Services app
trans-unit.target: Add authentication to your Mobile Services app

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This topic shows you how to authenticate users in Azure Mobile Services from your universal Windows app.
trans-unit.target: This topic shows you how to authenticate users in Azure Mobile Services from your universal Windows app.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you add authentication to the quickstart project using an identity provider that is supported by Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you add authentication to the quickstart project using an identity provider that is supported by Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: After being successfully authenticated and authorized by Mobile Services, the user ID value is displayed.
trans-unit.target: After being successfully authenticated and authorized by Mobile Services, the user ID value is displayed.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial is based on the Mobile Services quickstart.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial is based on the Mobile Services quickstart.

trans-unit.source: You must also first complete the tutorial [Get started with Mobile Services] or [Add Mobile Services to an existing app](mobile-services-dotnet-backend-windows-universal-dotnet-get-started-data.md).
trans-unit.target: You must also first complete the tutorial [Get started with Mobile Services] or [Add Mobile Services to an existing app](mobile-services-dotnet-backend-windows-universal-dotnet-get-started-data.md).

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE]This tutorial shows you how to use server-directed authentication for users in Windows Store and Windows Phone Store 8.1 apps.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE]This tutorial shows you how to use server-directed authentication for users in Windows Store and Windows Phone Store 8.1 apps.

trans-unit.source: For a Windows Phone 8.0 or Windows Phone Silverlight 8.1 app, see this version of [Get started with authentication in Mobile Services](mobile-services-dotnet-backend-windows-phone-get-started-users.md).
trans-unit.target: For a Windows Phone 8.0 or Windows Phone Silverlight 8.1 app, see this version of [Get started with authentication in Mobile Services](mobile-services-dotnet-backend-windows-phone-get-started-users.md).

trans-unit.source: Fore information about client-directed authentication, see [Logging in with Google, Microsoft and Facebook SDKs to Azure Mobile Services](http://azure.microsoft.com/blog/2014/10/27/logging-in-with-google-microsoft-and-facebook-sdks-to-azure-mobile-services/).
trans-unit.target: Fore information about client-directed authentication, see [Logging in with Google, Microsoft and Facebook SDKs to Azure Mobile Services](http://azure.microsoft.com/blog/2014/10/27/logging-in-with-google-microsoft-and-facebook-sdks-to-azure-mobile-services/).

trans-unit.source: 6.
trans-unit.target: 6.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, right-click the Windows Store project for the TodoList app and click **Set as StartUp Project**.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, right-click the Windows Store project for the TodoList app and click **Set as StartUp Project**.

trans-unit.source: 7.
trans-unit.target: 7.

trans-unit.source: In the shared project, open the App.xaml.cs project file, locate the definition for the [MobileServiceClient](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/microsoft.windowsazure.mobileservices.mobileserviceclient.aspx), and make sure that it is configured to connect to the mobile service running in Azure.
trans-unit.target: In the shared project, open the App.xaml.cs project file, locate the definition for the [MobileServiceClient](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/microsoft.windowsazure.mobileservices.mobileserviceclient.aspx), and make sure that it is configured to connect to the mobile service running in Azure.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE]When you use Visual Studio tools to connect your app to a Mobile Service, the tool generate two sets of **MobileServiceClient** definitions, one for each client platform.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE]When you use Visual Studio tools to connect your app to a Mobile Service, the tool generate two sets of **MobileServiceClient** definitions, one for each client platform.

trans-unit.source: This is a good time to simplify the generated code by unifying the `#if...#endif` wrapped **MobileServiceClient** definitions into a single unwrapped definition used by both versions of the app.
trans-unit.target: This is a good time to simplify the generated code by unifying the `#if...#endif` wrapped **MobileServiceClient** definitions into a single unwrapped definition used by both versions of the app.

trans-unit.source: You won't need to do this when you downloaded the quickstart app from the Azure Management portal.
trans-unit.target: You won't need to do this when you downloaded the quickstart app from the Azure Management portal.

trans-unit.source: 8.
trans-unit.target: 8.

trans-unit.source: Press the F5 key to run the Windows store app, and verify that an unhandled exception with a status code of 401 (Unauthorized) is raised after the app starts.
trans-unit.target: Press the F5 key to run the Windows store app, and verify that an unhandled exception with a status code of 401 (Unauthorized) is raised after the app starts.

trans-unit.source: This happens because the app attempts to access Mobile Services as an unauthenticated user, but the *TodoItem* table now requires authentication.
trans-unit.target: This happens because the app attempts to access Mobile Services as an unauthenticated user, but the *TodoItem* table now requires authentication.

trans-unit.source: Next, you will update the app to authenticate users before requesting resources from the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: Next, you will update the app to authenticate users before requesting resources from the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: Add authentication to the app
trans-unit.target: Add authentication to the app

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE]If you registered your Windows Store app package information with Mobile Services, you should call the LoginAsync method by supplying a value of **true** for the *useSingleSignOn* parameter.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE]If you registered your Windows Store app package information with Mobile Services, you should call the LoginAsync method by supplying a value of **true** for the *useSingleSignOn* parameter.

trans-unit.source: If you do not do this, your users will continue to be presented with a login prompt every time that the login method is called.
trans-unit.target: If you do not do this, your users will continue to be presented with a login prompt every time that the login method is called.
